parts:
Here’s a compact map of **modern directions that grow out of classical Galois theory** (fields, radicals, solvable groups) and what they’ve added in roughly the last few decades. I’ve grouped things by theme and pointed to why they matter beyond “solvability by radicals”.

---

# 1) Beyond radicals: “how hard is a polynomial to solve?”

**a) Resolvent degree (RD) & essential dimension (ed).**  
- *Idea:* Replace the yes/no of “solvable by radicals” with a **complexity measure** of the best possible tower of “elementary” covering maps needed to express roots.  
- **RD** (revived recently by Farb–Wolfson–Wood and others) quantifies the minimal depth of resolvent operations needed to solve a problem (e.g. general degree-n equation, lines on a cubic surface, etc.).  
- **Essential dimension** \(\mathrm{ed}(G)\) (Buhler–Reichstein → Brosnan–Reichstein–Vistoli, Karpenko–Merkurjev, …) asks for the **fewest parameters** needed to define a \(G\)-torsor. For \(S_n\) over \(\mathbb{C}\), \(\mathrm{ed}(S_n)=n-3\) for \(n\ge 5\). This reframes solvability questions as **minimal parameter counts**.

**b) Topological Galois theory (à la Arnold–Khovanskii).**  
- Uses **monodromy** and topology of branched covers to obstruct representability of solutions by radicals (or even by broader classes like generalized quadratures).  
- Gives robust, *coordinate-free* obstructions extending the classical “generic quintic” story.

**c) Algorithmic Galois theory.**  
- Fast, certified methods to **compute Galois groups** of polynomials (Stauduhar-type methods; van Hoeij–Klüners–Fieker refinements), factorization over number fields, and decision procedures for solvability by radicals.  
- Practical consequence: we can now **routinely determine** whether a concrete polynomial is solvable by radicals and, if so, produce radicals/parametrizations.

---

# 2) Inverse Galois & field arithmetic: from existence to distribution

**a) Inverse Galois problem (IGP).**  
- Large progress on realizing many finite groups as **Galois groups over \(\mathbb{Q}\)** via **rigidity**, **patching**, and **Hilbert irreducibility**; deep advances for families (regular realizations over \(\mathbb{Q}(t)\)) and many simple groups. The general IGP over \(\mathbb{Q}\) remains open.  
- **Patching over fields** (Harbater–Hartmann–Krashen): a flexible glueing technique that solves embedding problems and produces Galois extensions with prescribed local behavior.

**b) Counting extensions & Malle’s conjecture.**  
- A shift from existence to **statistics**: asymptotics for number fields with bounded discriminant and a fixed Galois group. Major progress for \(S_n\) (Bhargava’s work up to \(n=5\)), some families in other groups, and growing uniformity methods.

**c) PAC fields, Hilbertian fields, and “field arithmetic” (Fried–Jarden).**  
- Structural results on **absolute Galois groups**, largeness properties of fields, and **embedding problems** that generalize classical Hilbert irreducibility in a probabilistic/structural direction.

---

# 3) Geometric Galois theory: from polynomials to fundamental groups

**a) Grothendieck’s Galois theory of covers (étale \(\pi_1\)).**  
- Reinterprets classical Galois theory as the theory of **finite étale covers**; the **absolute Galois group** \(G_K\) acts on geometric objects (covers of curves), giving vast **Galois representations**.

**b) Anabelian geometry.**  
- For certain varieties (notably hyperbolic curves), the isomorphism class can be **recovered from its étale fundamental group** (Grothendieck’s anabelian conjectures; results of Mochizuki, Tamagawa, Pop, et al.).  
- Deep links to Diophantine geometry (e.g., Kim’s non-abelian Chabauty method for rational points).

**c) Dessins d’enfants & Belyi.**  
- Every curve over \(\overline{\mathbb{Q}}\) corresponds to a **combinatorial dessin** (Belyi). The absolute Galois group \(G_{\mathbb{Q}}\) acts on dessins; this yields concrete windows into the **mystery of \(G_{\mathbb{Q}}\)** (Ihara, Drinfeld, Grothendieck–Teichmüller).

---

# 4) Galois representations, \(p\)-adic Hodge theory, and Langlands

**a) From solvability to modularity.**  
- Wiles–Taylor–… modularity theorems linked **2-dimensional \(p\)-adic Galois representations** with **modular forms**, inaugurating a wave of **modularity-lifting** techniques (Kisin, Calegari–Geraghty, et al.).  
- Classical “solvable by radicals” corresponds to **solvable Galois groups**; in the modern picture, many problems become: *what automorphic data does a representation come from?*

**b) \(p\)-adic Hodge theory (Fontaine and successors).**  
- Classifies \(p\)-adic Galois representations (crystalline, de Rham, semistable), relating them to linear algebra over period rings.  
- **Fontaine–Mazur conjecture** and deformations of Galois representations organize major parts of modern number theory.

---

# 5) Differential / difference / parameterized Galois theories

**a) Differential Galois (Picard–Vessiot, Kolchin; modern: van der Put–Singer).**  
- A perfect analogue of field-Galois theory for **linear ODEs**: Liouvillian/elementary integrability corresponds to **solvable differential Galois group**.  
- **Kovacic’s algorithm** gives a decision procedure for second-order equations.  
- Modern work extends to **difference** and **\(q\)-difference** equations, and **parameterized** theories (Cassidy–Singer), with Tannakian formulations.

**b) Tannakian formalism & motivic Galois.**  
- Many Galois theories (classical, differential, Hodge/motivic) fit into **neutral Tannakian categories**, where the “Galois group” is the **affine group scheme of tensor automorphisms**.  
- In the **motivic** setting (Grothendieck, Nori, André), one seeks a “Galois group of periods”, tying algebraic cycles to transcendence questions (Kontsevich–Zagier).

---

# 6) Positive characteristic & wild phenomena

**a) Abhyankar’s conjectures (solved: Raynaud; Harbater).**  
- Precise description of finite groups occurring as Galois groups of covers of the affine line over **algebraically closed fields of char \(p\)**, reflecting **wild ramification** that has no analogue over \(\mathbb{C}\).

**b) Pro-\(\ell\) and pro-\(p\) Galois groups; cohomology of number fields.**  
- Deep structure theorems and obstructions via **Galois cohomology**, norm residue isomorphisms (Bloch–Kato), and the modern use of cohomological dimension to constrain realizable groups.

---

# 7) Invariants of “how explicit” Galois theory can be

**a) Noether’s problem & rationality of \(k(x_g)^G\).**  
- When is the field of invariants **purely transcendental**? Counterexamples (Saltman, Bogomolov) link to **unramified Brauer groups** and stable rationality problems.

**b) Explicit class field theory beyond CM fields (Hilbert’s 12th).**  
- Ongoing attempts to generalize Kronecker–Weber to **explicit generators** for abelian extensions of number fields (e.g., Stark/Brumer–Stark heuristics, Rubin–Stark, Gross–Stark). This is the “explicit solvability” frontier for **abelian** Galois groups.

---

# How this reframes “solvability by radicals”

- **Radicals ↔ solvable groups** gave a dichotomy. Modern work provides **graded invariants**:  
  - **RD/ed** quantify the minimal *functional/combinatorial complexity*.  
  - **Differential Galois** characterizes integrability by **group-theoretic solvability** in ODEs (a direct analogue).  
  - **Topological/monodromy obstructions** generalize “no radicals” to broader classes of formulas.  
  - **Tannakian/motivic** perspectives replace radicals by **tensor-functorial symmetries**; “solving” means understanding the **group scheme** acting on solutions.

---

# Representative open problems & frontiers

- **Inverse Galois over \(\mathbb{Q}\):** realize every finite group? (We have many, but not all.)  
- **Malle’s conjecture:** correct exponents and secondary terms for counting fields with group \(G\).  
- **Fontaine–Mazur:** which \(p\)-adic Galois reps come from geometry/automorphic forms?  
- **Hilbert’s 12th (explicit class field theory):** explicit generators for abelian extensions of general number fields.  
- **Resolvent degree:** sharp values for classical moduli problems and high \(n\) polynomials.  
- **Anabelian for number fields:** full scope of reconstructing arithmetic from \(G_K\).  
- **Transcendence/periods:** “Galois theory of periods” and the structure of motivic Galois groups.

---

# What to read (concise, field-standard)

- **Field arithmetic / inverse Galois:** Fried–Jarden, *Field Arithmetic*; Malle–Matzat, *Inverse Galois Theory*.  
- **Galois cohomology / number fields:** Neukirch–Schmidt–Wingberg, *Cohomology of Number Fields*.  
- **Geometric/étale viewpoint:** Szamuely, *Galois Groups and Fundamental Groups*; Serre, *Topics in Galois Theory*.  
- **Differential/difference Galois:** van der Put–Singer, *Galois Theory of Linear Differential Equations* (and *… Difference Equations*); Kovacic’s algorithm notes.  
- **Tannakian & motives:** Deligne–Milne, *Tannakian Categories*; André, *Motives, Transcendental Numbers, and Periods*.  
- **Essential dimension / RD:** survey papers by Reichstein (ed), and the monograph work by Farb–Wolfson–Wood on **resolvent degree**.  
- **Topological Galois:** A. Khovanskii, *Topological Galois Theory*.

---

If you want, I can tailor a **graduate-level reading path** that starts from classical Galois, goes through étale/fundamental groups and Galois cohomology, then splits into **(i)** inverse Galois/field arithmetic, **(ii)** differential/Tannakian/motivic, and **(iii)** Langlands/\(p\)-adic Hodge—the three arcs that most cleanly extend “solvability by radicals” today.
